docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey has the nation's seventh lowest birth rate among teen-agers, according to a study released by Rutgers University last week. The rate was 35 births for each 1,000 teen-agers in 1996, the latest year for which statistics are available. New Hampshire had the lowest rate, 29, and Mississippi the highest, 76. The national rate was 54 per 1,000.

headline.main: Teen-Age Birth Rate Seventh Lowest in Country

docs.abstract: Rutgers University study finds that New Jersey has nation's seventh lowest birth rate among teen-agers, 35 births per 1,000 teen-agers in 1996; New Hampshire had lowest rate, 29, and Mississippi highest, 76, with national average of 54 per 1,000 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE trouble began when Bobbie Gallagher noticed that her 2-year-old daughter was behaving strangely, obsessively spinning and scrupulously setting her toys in rows. Alanna Gallagher turned out to have autism, a rare neurological disorder of unknown cause. So did Alanna's little brother. So did about 40 other children who lived in the Gallaghers' town of Brick, N.J., near the seashore.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Probing Disease Clusters: Easier to Spot Than Prove

docs.abstract: Investigations of reports of disease clusters and difficulty of proving any scientific link to pollutants or other factors discussed; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Marcia Tucker's article ''Museums Experiment With New Exhibition Strategies'' [Jan. 10] makes an impassioned argument for art institutions to assist diverse audiences in becoming collaborators in the production of culture. A noted innovator in her own right, Ms. Tucker holds a vision of a democratic museum that contrasts sharply with that expressed by Glenn D. Lowry, the director of the Museum of Modern Art, in his adjoining essay titled ''The State of the Art Museum, Ever Changing.'' Mr. Lowry's conventional but refreshingly honest commentary states that museums are ultimately about a rarefied experience -- and questions if it is feasible or desirable for museums to ever be used and enjoyed by all. Proponents of esthetic populism should heed this well. Experiments aimed at democratizing high culture remain a serious threat to the institutional status quo, and it is far too early to think that real change is at hand.
docs.abstract: Letter from Gregory Sholette, former Curator of Education for New Museum of Contemporary Art and a co-founder of REPOhistory artists collective, comments on Marcia Tucker's Jan 10 article Museums Experiment With New Exhibition Strategies
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Marcia Tucker's article ''Museums Experiment With New Exhibition Strategies'' [Jan. 10] makes an impassioned argument for art institutions to assist diverse audiences in becoming collaborators in the production of culture. A noted...

docs.lead_paragraph: Holding her tiny 6-month-old daughter close to her shoulder, Heather Howarth talked about Government scientists who had come into her town to study whether anything in the environment was causing local children to develop autism, a disorder that affects a child's ability to communicate and function socially. ''My husband heard about it on the radio, and he called to tell me, 'If you let her drink the water, I'll kill you,' '' Mrs. Howarth said, pulling a white sweater up protectively over her baby's head as she stood outside a shopping center here. ''I heard they found 400 cases of autism here.''

headline.main: Autism Has a Town Struggling With Fear; With Causes Unclear, Parents Doubt Safety

docs.abstract: Many residents of Brick Township, NJ, are fearful for their children since Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that it was investigating what may be unusually high number of autism cases and whether there is environmental cause; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Intel Corporation has acquiesced to privacy interests by stating that the identifying serial number in its new Pentium III chips will be disabled when delivered to customers (front page, Jan. 26). Yet Intel's action is not enough. The chip identification number is like pregnancy. Either it is present or it is not; there is no half way.

headline.main: Internet Bubble Is Ready to Burst

docs.abstract: Ben Myers letter warns that disabling serial numbers in individual new Pentium II chips will not suffice to protect users' privacy, since insidious clandestine program could enable chip numbers again (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The risk of an H.I.V.-infected woman passing the AIDS virus to her baby during birth is nearly eliminated if the woman takes a standard AIDS drug during pregnancy and has a Caesarean. The benefits of the drug, AZT, have been known for five years. The added advantage of a Caesarean was suspected but had not been proved until a large study released today.

headline.main: Caesarean Plus Drug Is Proved To Reduce Transfer of H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Study reports near elimination of risk of HIV-infected woman passing AIDS virus to her baby during birth if woman takes AZT, standard AIDS drug, during pregnancy and has Caesarean; new data is scheduled to be published in Mar 31 issue of New England Journal of Medicine, which posted article early on Internet because of its importance to public health (M)
docs.snippet: The risk of an H.I.V.-infected woman passing the AIDS virus to her baby during birth is nearly eliminated if the woman takes a standard AIDS drug during pregnancy and has a Caesarean.    The benefits of the drug, AZT, have been known for five years....

docs.lead_paragraph: Talk shows and women's magazines are full of the matters raised by Nancy Savoca in her new film, ''The 24-Hour Woman,'' in which a woman with a high-powered job tries to cope with the high-powered hassles of balancing career and family. But somebody on the other side of the camera has clearly been here and done this, and boy, does it show on screen. Dedicating the film to her own mother, Ms. Savoca describes the joy and frustration of new motherhood in workaday detail, right down to the last unmade bed. ''Nobody threw food around!'' one woman marvels about office life, returning to the work force after having stayed home bringing up children for a long spell.

headline.main: Women's Work: 9 to 5 In Daydreams Only

docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews film The 24-Hour Woman, directed by Nancy Savoca and starring Rosie Perez and Patti LuPone; photo; film has world premiere at Sundance Film Festival, and opens series The Feminine Eye: Twenty Years of Women's Cinema; series is sponsored by Brooklyn Academy of Music and New York Women in Film and Television; schedule listed; Savoca retrospective also set at American Museum of the Moving Image (M)
